qas.question: Who suffered a great amount of losses battling the Roman army?
What did Rome refuse to do in their relations with Pyrrhus?
What military leader does the term Pyrrhic victory come from?
What ultimately caused Pyrrhus to vacate completely from the country of Italy?

answers.text: Seeing little hope for further gains

qas.question: In what year did the Battle of Beneventum take place?

context: Despite early victories, Pyrrhus found his position in Italy untenable. Rome steadfastly refused to <a1_0>negotiate<a1_0/> with <a0_0>Pyrrhus<a0_0/> as long as his army remained in Italy. Facing unacceptably heavy losses from each encounter with the Roman army, <a2_0>Pyrrhus<a2_0/> withdrew from the peninsula (hence the term "Pyrrhic victory"). In <a4_0>275 BC<a4_0/>, Pyrrhus again met the Roman army at the Battle of Beneventum. While Beneventum was indecisive, Pyrrhus realised his army had been exhausted and reduced by years of foreign campaigns. <a3_0>Seeing little hope for further gains<a3_0/>, he withdrew completely from Italy.
